Award.AbstractNarration:
Student success in algebra continues to be a problem as many U.S. students are underprepared when they enter high school. Students who fail algebra in the ninth grade are significantly less likely than their peers to graduate from high school on time. This project intends to test a common support strategy for at-risk students that provides an extra period of algebra, commonly known as a "double dose" condition. The Intensified Algebra (IA) is an intervention that addresses both the academic and non-academic needs of students. It is set of cohesive, integrated, and rigorous resources that builds student motivation and confidence. IA uses a blended model of instruction with a strong technology component designed to support the productive use of expanded instructional time that has shown evidence of promise in earlier studies.

This project is intended to rigorously test the impact of IA on student outcomes in a school-level random assignment design involving 6 districts, 55 high schools and over 4,000 9th grade students across two cohorts. Within each district, eligible schools are randomly assigned to either implement IA or to use the school's already established "double dose" algebra course. Analyses will use hierarchical linear models that explicitly take into account the clustering of students within classrooms and classrooms within schools. The study investigates short-term outcomes including end-of-9th grade algebra learning, passing rate for algebra I and attitudes toward mathematics. Longer-term outcomes include subsequent course-taking patterns and performances. The study examines fidelity of implementation and key implementation factors with descriptive and correlational analyses.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Intensified Algebra Efficacy Study was a randomized controlled trial that examined the efficacy of Intensified Algebra, a digital, conceptual curriculum designed to support 90 minutes of daily algebra instruction for ninth-grade students 1-3 grade levels behind in mathematics learning. The study included two cohorts of schools that each participated in the project for one year, either during the 2015-16 or 2016-17 school year. The combined sample included 48 schools, 96 teachers, and approximately 3,000 ninth-grade students. Participating schools were primarily from urban and suburban communities located in the Midwest, Northeast, Mid-Atlantic, or Southern regions of the U.S. Prior to the year of study participation, schools were randomly assigned to either implement Intensified Algebra (treatment group) or the pre-existing, extended-time algebra course offered to struggling students (control group). The study assessed impacts of the program after one year of implementation on students' algebra learning, academic mindset, and likelihood of passing Algebra I by the end of the year. The study also measured implementation fidelity of the Intensified Algebra program and conducted exploratory analyses of the association of implementation fidelity with student outcomes.

Impact analyses indicated that Intensified Algebra students performed worse than students in the control group on two of the three study outcomes: the study's algebra assessment (Acuity) and self-reported mindset measures. Intensified Algebra students correctly answered approximately 1.5 fewer questions on the 25-question algebra assessment than control students, and performance was low in both groups. On an end-of-year survey, Intensified Algebra students reported lower levels of metacognition, self-efficacy, and persistence in mathematics compared to students in the control group. For the third outcome, passing algebra by the end of the year, the study found no difference in passing rates between Intensified Algebra and control students, and the majority of students received a passing grade.

Implementation analyses revealed that teachers used fewer units of the curriculum than desired by the program developers, and such insufficient coverage of the content may have contributed to the results. Implementation fidelity was higher for specific features of the curriculum, including use of lessons designed to help students see intelligence as malleable and associate success in mathematics with effort. Exploratory analyses found no significant associations between variation in implementation fidelity and student outcomes.
